content.raw: I *think* the first one could be a problem with the message taking too long to be received. We could increase max sleep times to account for this kind of thing...
content.html: I think the first one could be a problem with the message taking too long to be received. We could increase max sleep times to account for this kind of thing...

content.raw: Just one comment about a more descriptive variable name. Looks good.
content.html: Just one comment about a more descriptive variable name. Looks good.

content.raw:
For the first one, that test is not directly modified by this pull request.

For the second one, I've seen lots of crashes like that. It's likely a transport problem.
content.html:
For the first one, that test is not directly modified by this pull request.

For the second one, I've seen lots of crashes like that. It's likely a transport problem.

content.raw: I ran it in a loop and it passed over 40 times before I stopped it.
content.html: I ran it in a loop and it passed over 40 times before I stopped it.

content.raw:
I ran the test 40 times and ran into 2 issues:

1 failure
~~~
FAIL!  : UndoTest::UndoResetWorld() 'newTime == gazebo::common::Time::Zero' returned FALSE. ()
   Loc: [/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/undo.cc(842)]
~~~

1 crash

~~~
INTEGRATION_undo: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::transport::Connection; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::transport::Connection*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
~~~

it's probably going to be very difficult to reproduce...
content.html:
I ran the test 40 times and ran into 2 issues:

1 failure

FAIL!  : UndoTest::UndoResetWorld() 'newTime == gazebo::common::Time::Zero' returned FALSE. ()
   Loc: [/home/ian/depot/clones/gazebo6/test/integration/undo.cc(842)]

1 crash

INTEGRATION_undo: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:653: typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::transport::Connection; typename boost::detail::sp_member_access<T>::type = gazebo::transport::Connection*]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.

it's probably going to be very difficult to reproduce...

content.raw: Is `visualsToPublish` a more descriptive name than `visToPub`?
content.html: Is visualsToPublish a more descriptive name than visToPub?

content.raw: `const auto &vis` ?
content.html: const auto &vis ?

content.raw: Thanks. Please let me know if you manage to reproduce the issue.
content.html: Thanks. Please let me know if you manage to reproduce the issue.

content.raw:
Sounds like it could be intermittent failures. I'll run it in a loop and see what happens.

I don't know why the jenkins console log does this, but it seems to lose some of the console output from qtests. It has the line number in the test results section that I linked though (which it gets from the junit xml file):

~~~
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/gazebo/test/integration/undo.cc:907
 :: 'box->GetWorldPose() == boxFinalPose' returned FALSE. ()
~~~
content.html:
Sounds like it could be intermittent failures. I'll run it in a loop and see what happens.

I don't know why the jenkins console log does this, but it seems to lose some of the console output from qtests. It has the line number in the test results section that I linked though (which it gets from the junit xml file):

/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/gazebo/test/integration/undo.cc:907
 :: 'box->GetWorldPose() == boxFinalPose' returned FALSE. ()

content.raw:
I ran [another](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/679/#showFailuresLink) test and it passed.

I'm not being able to reproduce the failure locally and the [plain text](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/678/consoleText) output for the build with the faling test says it failed but doesn't really show the failing lines. Is it possible there was something weird with Jenkins?
content.html:
I ran another test and it passed.

I'm not being able to reproduce the failure locally and the plain text output for the build with the faling test says it failed but doesn't really show the failing lines. Is it possible there was something weird with Jenkins?

content.raw: Thanks, I'll take a look at it.
content.html: Thanks, I'll take a look at it.
